Ethyl glycolate (EGly) is a platform molecule in various fields, which has been widely applied for the production of various valuable chemicals. Despite being a traditional catalyst for the conversion of diethyl oxalate (DEO) to EGly, Ag/SiO2 catalyst exhibits insufficient activity. The present study introduces a novel preparation method that couples H2O2 reduction with deposition precipitation to augment the performance of the catalyst. Performance results show that Ag/SiO2 catalyst prepared by the new method attains a DEO conversion of 95.6% and an EGly selectivity of 78.0%, showing respective improvements of 10.0 and 15.2% over excess impregnation-evaporating solvent method. Characterization results show that the average silver particles size of Ag/SiO2 catalyst prepared by the new method is 6 nm, which is 1/2 of the excess impregnation-evaporation solvent method. Simultaneously, it contains a greater quantity of Ag0. The smaller and more uniform particles offer greater active site density, leading to enhanced DEO conversion. An increased presence of Ag0 diminishes DEO overactivation and inhibits the dissociative adsorption of H2. Moreover, the amplified quantity of Ag0 could be attributed to the reduced interfacial charge transport triggered by metal-support interactions (MSIs). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethyl glycolate Diethyl oxalate hydrogenation Metal-support interaction High dispersion Ag/SiO2 catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethyl glycolate (EGly) is extensively utilized as an intermediate and solvent in the chemical, pharmaceutical, dye, and related industries due to its distinctive combination of ester and hydroxyl group structures [1–4]. It plays a crucial role in the production of glycine, ethylene glycol, vanillin, and notably ethanoic acid, which serves as a precursor for biodegradable plastics [5]. The coal-based oxalate esters hydrogenation pathway is one of the several methods for the synthesis of EGly [6,7]. This approach provides significant product yields, operates under mild reaction conditions, and is environmentally sustainable, in accordance with the principles of green chemistry advocated in contemporary discourse [3,8]. Compared to the extensively researched methyl glycolate (MG), EGly exhibits greater potential owing to its safety and environmental advantages [3]. Silver-based catalyst is a classic catalyst for the hydrogenation of oxalate esters [9,10]. The d-band of silver is fully occupied, which restricts the adsorption of hydrogen and prevents excessive hydrogenation of DEO [11]. Although silver-based catalysts exhibit the high selectivity for EGly, their industrial application is constrained by the heavy costs [12]. To improve the specific activity of silver species in catalysts, researchers have conducted numerous studies. These studies include the addition of the second active metal component [13–18], doping with non-metallic components [19–21], selection and modification of supports [22–26], design of nano-reactors [27,28] and optimization of catalyst preparation methods [11,25]. In particular, optimizing the catalyst preparation method is a straightforward and high efficienct approach to improve the specific activity of silver. Yin et al. prepared catalysts with highly dispersed silver particles by sol-gel method, which result in the significant increase in catalytic activity [11]. Subsequent research by Dong et al. revealed that the sizes of silver particles determines the catalytic performance, which result from the trade-off between electronic and geometric effects in the catalyst [29]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop a preparation method capable of synthesizing suitable size silver particles. In metal/support heterogeneous catalytic systems, the interactions between the metal and support play a crucial role in determining the activity and stability of catalysts. These interactions, known as metal-support interactions (MSIs), have attracted significant attention. Recent studies have shown that too strong or too weak MSIs trigger Ostwald ripening or particle migration and agglomeration, respectively [30]. Moreover, MSIs are usually accompanied by interfacial charge transfer, resulting in significant modifications to the electronic structure of the metal component [31]. Numerous studies have demonstrated the influence of electronic perturbation of silver species on catalytic activity, especially in the initial hydrogenation of DEO [22,25,29]. Therefore, it is essential to find new approaches, especially preparation methods, to modulate the strength of MSIs in intrinsically adapted loaded metal-based catalysts. MSIs widely occur on reducible [32–34] and inert support [35,36]. The strategy for modulating MSIs includes various approaches, such as thermal treatment [37], the addition of reducing agents [38], reduction-oxidation cycles [39], surface deposition [40], etc. However, there is a scarcity of reports addressing the effects of reducing agent addition on MSIs.Rui et al. reported that the SMSI state in Pt/TiO2 could be induced during the liquid-phase reduction with NaBH4 or formaldehyde as the reducing agent at room temperature [38]. Grabchenko et al. found that the valence state of Ce in CeOx before impregnation of loaded metals directly affects the strength of MSIs [41]. So far, major studies focusing on the impact of reducing agents on MSIs over reducible supports, where the extent of reduction strongly correlates with the strength of MSIs. For inert supports such as SiO2, C etc., whether the reducing agent affects the MSIs of them remains to be seen. In this study, we have integrated the reducing agent H2O2 into the conventional deposition-precipitation method. This novel H2O2 reduction method enables the preparation of small-sized Ag/SiO2 catalysts with uniform particles. Meanwhile, we investigate the effect of reducing agent on the MSIs in the inert support-based loaded metal catalysts. Building upon this, we further investigate the effect of MSIs-mediated interfacial charge transfer on the catalyst activity. The results of the study could provide a new perspective for the precise construction and design of loaded metal catalysts for DEO hydrogenation to EGly. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials Diethyl oxalate (DEO), ethyl glycolate (EGly) and ethylene glycol (EG) were purchased from Aladdin. Ammonia (NH3·H2O), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), silver nitrate (AgNO3) and anhydrous ethanol (EtOH) were provided by Guangdong Guanghua Sci-Tech Co., Ltd. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and Dodecylamine (DDA) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemical reagents were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of the SiO2 support SiO2 is prepared by the conventional wet template agent method. Typically, 3.33 g of DDA, 35 ml of EtOH and 35 ml of deionized water are added to the beaker. Stir vigorously to induce complete dissolution of DDA. Subsequently, 15.0 ml TEOS is slowly dropped into the vigorously stirred DDA solution at a droplet rate of 20 drops/min. Stirring was continued for 4 h after the end of drop addition, followed by aging for 24 h. The aged suspension is filtered and washed, and then dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. Finally, the dried powder is calcined in static air at 500 °C for 6 h to remove the template agent DDA. 2.2.2 Preparation of the xAg/SiO2 by H2O2 reduction methods Typically, 0.315 g of AgNO3 is dissolved in 10 ml of deionized water, followed by a slow drop of ammonia until the precipitate is completely dissolved. At this point, the silver-ammonia solution is prepared. Then, the silver ammonia solution is poured into the silica suspension (100 ml of deionized water containing 2 g of SiO2) and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Subsequently, 40 ml of 30 wt.% H2O2 solution is added slowly at a rate of 20 drops/min, accompanies by strong stirring. The whole process is conducted in an ice water bath to reduce the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. After all drops were completed, stirring is continued in an ice water bath for 2 h. The suspension is then filtered and washed, and the product is dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. The dried powder is calcined in static air at 500 °C for 6 h to obtain 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst. Rest of the catalysts are prepared by simply changing the amount of AgNO3. The nomenclature of this series of catalysts is xAg/SiO2-HR (x stands for theoretical loading of x wt.% silver, HR stands for H2O2 reduction method). The reaction principle of hydrogen peroxide reduction is as follows: Ag ( N H 3 ) 2 OH + SiOH → + Ag ( N H 3 ) 2 − OSi + H 2 O 2 [ Ag ( N H 3 ) 2 ] + + H 2 O 2 → 2 Ag + 2 NH 4 + + 2 N H 3 + O 2 2.2.3 Preparation of the 10Ag/SiO2 by excess impregnation-evaporating solvent methods Traditionally, 0.315 g of AgNO3 is dissolved in 10 ml of deionized water. The completely dissolved silver nitrate solution is then poured into the silica suspension (100 ml of water contains 2 g of silica). The solution is stirred at 40 °C for 3 h and then placed in a desiccator at 80 °C overnight. The dried powder is calcined under static air at 500 °C to obtain final catalyst. The catalyst is entitled 10Ag/SiO2-EE (10 stands for theoretical loading of 10 wt.% silver, EE stands for excess impregnation-evaporating solvent method. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations Multiple characterization approaches such as powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) etc. are used to reveal the presence form and electronic properties of silver species on the catalyst. Except for the H2-TPR test, the samples used for characterization are all reduced catalysts. Prior to the catalytic measurements and characterization (except for H2-TPR), the catalyst was reduced in a stream of 60 ml/min of 50% H2/N2 at 300 °C for 2 h under atmospheric pressure. Further detailed information regarding the characterization is provided in Supporting Information. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic performances for DEO hydrogenation were evaluated in a stainless fixed-bed tubular continuous flow reactor (inner diameter 8 mm, length 550 mm) equipped with a condensation tank. Typically, 800 mg of catalyst was loaded into the middle of the reaction tube, with an amount of quartz wool at the top and bottom of the catalyst. The catalyst was reduced by 60 mL/min of 50% H2/50% N2 at 300 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 2 K min−1. After cooling to the reaction temperature, the fixed bed was rammed to 1.5 MPa with pure hydrogen. The 10 wt.% DEO/EtOH solution and H2 were fed into the reactor at a H2/DEO molar of 200 and a LHSV of DEO was 0.2 h−1. The products were collected by a condensation tank for 2 h at each temperature point, and analyzed on a gas chromatograph (HOPE GC-9860-5CNJ) fitted with a PEG 2000 capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion of DMO and the selectivity of product were calculated based on the following equations: Conversion ( % ) = n ( D M O ) in − n ( D M O ) out n ( D M O ) in × 100 % Selectivity ( % ) = n ( EGly ) or n ( EG ) n ( DMO ) in − n ( DMO ) out × 100 % Yield ( % ) = Selectivity × Conversion 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance and structure of catalysts 3.1.1 Screening silver loadings and temperature A series of xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts were evaluated for DEO hydrogenation catalytic activities, starting with the screening of optimal silver loadings. Fig. 1 a and b show the DEO conversion and EGly selectivity over the xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts. Both catalysts display an almost linear relationship between DEO conversion or EGly selectivity and reaction temperature. DEO conversion shows a positive correlation with temperature, whereas EGly selectivity shows a negative correlation with temperature. In consecutive hydrogenation reactions, heightened reactant activation typically diminishes control over the extent of hydrogenation, resulting in a subsequent decrease in the selectivity of the initial hydrogenation product [42–44]. Consequently, regulating the degree of activation of ester groups represents a pivotal strategy for enhancing EGly selectivity [44]. The EGly yield, determined by both conversion and selectivity, is a more suitable indicator to consider in catalyst activity evaluation. Fig. 1c demonstrates that the EGly yield of all catalysts follows a volcano-like trend as the temperature increases. The 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst exhibits the highest EGly yield at 260 °C. Consequently, the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and a temperature of 260 °C are considered the optimal catalyst and the ideal reaction temperature, respectively. Similarly, the yield of EGly demonstrates an approximate volcano-shaped trend with increasing silver loading. The yield decreases significantly when the loading reaches 15 wt.%, likely because of reduced silver exposure caused by the aggregation of silver nanoparticles. 3.1.2 Catalysts activity and stability To highlight the superiority of the H2O2 reduction method, 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst and the 10AgSiO2-EE catalyst were employed for DEO hydrogenation to EGly. Fig. S1 demonstrates that the 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst possesses a significant advantage across all temperature ranges, surpassing the performance of the 10AgSiO2-EE catalyst in terms of both DEO conversion and EGly selectivity. The performance comparison of silver-based catalysts is shown in Table 1 . The EGly yields of the two catalysts are shown in Fig. 1d. For comparison, the 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst achieves an EGly yield of up to 79.2% at 260 °C, which is 20% higher than that of the 10AgSiO2-EE catalyst. On average, the EGly yield of the 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst is 19.7% higher than that of the 10AgSiO2-EE catalyst across the entire temperature range tested. The inherently high activity of the 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst highlights the substantial impact of preparation methods on catalyst performance, suggesting that preparation methods lead to notable modifications in the catalyst structure. Apart from catalyst activity, catalyst stability is also a crucial factor. The long-term stability and cyclic stability of 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst are shown in Figs. S2 and S3. In the 100 h long-term test and the 3-cycle test, the activity of the 10AgSiO2-HR catalyst exhibited no significant decline, indicating its excellent stability. 3.1.3 FTIR absorption spectroscopy FTIR absorption spectroscopy is employed to identify the structure of SiO2 in the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 2 a. The asymmetric, symmetric, and rocking bending vibrations of Si-O-Si bonds are detected at 1093, 798, and 469 cm−1, respectively. The bands at 3747 and 3442 cm–1 are attributed to stretching vibration of isolated SiOH and H-bonded SiOH (or molecular water) [36]. The existence of Si-OH and Si-O-Si groups confirms the successful synthesis of supported SiO2. In the range of the stretching vibration of -OH, the band of H-bonded SiOH and the broad band of molecular water are intermingled, which makes it difficult to distinguish. However, the bending vibrations of SiOH and water molecules exhibit distinct characteristics. The bending vibration band of the water molecule is at 1628 cm−1 while the band of SiOH at 981 cm−1 [50]. It is evident that isolated SiOH species exist on the surfaces of both the 10Ag/SiO2-HR and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalysts after calcination, however, the concentration of H-bonded SiOH differs significantly between them. The band at 981 cm−1 is apparently on 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst while it is almost indiscernible for 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. This observation suggests that a higher concentration of SiOH groups on the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst participated in bonding with the silver precursor during catalyst synthesis, potentially contributing to the enhanced metal-support interactions on the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. 3.1.4 Textural properties of catalysts The textural properties of the catalyst, including BET surface, pore volume and pore diameter, significantly impact the adsorption of gas feedstocks [26]. N2 physisorption measurements are employed to identify the differences in textural properties between xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. Fig. S4 shows the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts and SiO2 support, both of which demonstrate characteristic Type IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis loops. This is the common characteristic in homogeneous mesoporous materials [26]. Overall, N2 adsorption decreases with increasing loading. As the loading increased from 0 to 5%, the shape of the hysteresis loop remained the shape, indicating the uniform dispersion of silver microcrystals on both the outer and inner surfaces of the catalysts at low loading. However, when the loading exceeded 10%, the shape of the hysteresis loop changed significantly, suggesting the blockage of specific pores and alteration of the catalyst's pore structure under high loading. A similar phenomenon has been observed in previous studies [26], leading us to hypothesize that this change might be attributed to the obstruction of specific types of SiO2 pores by silver particals. Table 2 illustrates the reduction in BET surface areas and pore volumes of the xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts as the silver loading increases, further supporting the enlargement of metal particles during the loading increasing. Fig. 2b compares the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. The hysteresis loop of the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst is significantly obscured, indicating severe pore blockage. Comparing the BET surfaces and pore volumes of 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst, it could be found that the BET surface and pore volume of the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst are significantly lower than those of the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst. The above results suggest the presence of larger silver particles in the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst, which contribute to the serious blockage of the catalyst's pore structure. This observation might partially explain the superior activity exhibited by the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst. 3.2 Identification of silver species In the above exploration of the catalyst structures, it is found that the support structures of the catalysts derived from different preparation methods are consistent, while the particle sizes of the silver particles differ significantly. Consequently, the differences in the activities of the catalysts probably originate from the silver species and its interaction with the support. Silver species, as adsorption and activation sites for H2 and DEO, whose existence forms significantly affect the performance of the catalysts [22,29]. In terms of the electronic structure, silver species are divided into Ag+ and Ag0; As regards the geometric structure, silver species are classified as silver single atoms, silver clusters and silver particles [29]. In this section, along the structure of silver species, we investigate the specific forms of silver species present on catalysts and their differences. 3.2.1 XRD analysis Fig. 2c shows the XRD patterns of xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts and SiO2. The pure phase SiO2 exhibits only a broad diffraction peak around 22°, confirming its amorphous nature. With the increase of silver loading, four new diffraction peaks attributed to silver species emerge and strengthen. These peaks occur at 38.1°, 44.3°, 64.4°, and 77.5°, corresponding to the (100), (200), (220), and (311) facets of cubic monolithic silver (PDF 04-0783), respectively. The gradually increasing peak intensity indicates the growth of silver particles with higher loading, aligning with the N2 physisorption measurements. XRD patterns reveal no characteristic peaks of silver oxide, probably owes to its low content and high dispersion. Additionally, the limited resolution of XRD prevents the detection of silver clusters. Fig. 2d displays the XRD pattern comparisons between the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. The similar diffraction peaks of both indicate the successful preparation of the Ag/SiO2 catalyst. The similar silver particle diffraction peak widths and intensities imply the congruence of primary grain [51], which enhance the comparability of the both. Figs. S5 and S6 show XRD patterns of used xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts. The approximately constant patterns illustrate the stability of the catalyst. Additionally, Fig. S7 presents the XRD patterns of the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst before and after calcination. Both approximate patterns suggest that the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst maintains the Ag0 state prior to calcination, potentially contributing to its superior activity. 3.2.2 TEM images TEM was used to determine the size of the silver particles. The size of silver particles on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst is shown in Fig. 3 a and Fig. 3b, respectively. Both catalysts exhibit silver particles loaded in a spherical shape. Silver particles on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst are uniformly dispersed, exhibiting a small particle size and primarily distributed in the range of 5–8 nm. Conversely, the silver particles on the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalysts exhibit a wide particle size distribution, predominantly ranging from 5 to 20 nm. Generally, primary grains agglomerate during calcination to form particles, which follows the Ostwald ripening mechanism [52]. The similar primary grain sizes and greatly differing particle sizes of the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst imply that the degree of ripening is different between them. The reason for this discrepancy might originate from the presence state of the silver species before calcination, i.e., Ag0 in the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and Ag+ in the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. In addition, the degree of ripening correlates with the metal-support interactions (MSIs) [30], which implies a possible difference of MSIs in the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. 3.2.3 UV–vis DRS spectrum The optical properties of solid materials are intimately related to the microstructure, e.g., electronic states, defect sites and energy level structures [26]. Silver surface plasma exhibits oscillatory absorption when exposed to UV–vis light. Different silver species exhibit distinct responses in specific wavelength ranges, enabling the identification of silver species [22]. Fig. 4 shows the UV–vis DRS spectra of 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst. The samples have three absorption peaks in the 220–600 nm region. These peaks are located at 250, 300, and 400 nm, corresponding to isolated Ag+, Agn δ+, and silver particles, respectively [26,29]. It should be noted that the peaks of the pure SiO2 and Ag+ are too close to be separated. However, the signals from the SiO2 support in both the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst with the same mass and thickness should be identical. Therefore, the concentration of Ag+ could be distinguished by semi-quantitative analysis. A semi-quantitative comparison of the peak intensities reveals that the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst silver species exist as particles more. In contrast, the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst presents more Ag+ and Agn δ+. The peak of silver particles at 400 nm on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst exhibits a blue shift, suggesting smaller silver particle sizes, which is consistent with the TEM and BET results. The above results elucidate the geometric structures of silver species on different catalysts. Specifically, the silver species on the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst exist as large-sized silver particles and massive clusters, whereas the silver species on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst exist as small-sized silver particles and few clusters. Regarding the electronic structure, the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst exhibits a higher abundance of Ag+, whereas the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst contains a larger proportion of Ag0. Furthermore, the presence of Ag+ indicates the occurrence of interfacial charge transfer induced by our MSIs [11]. 3.2.4 MA-TPD In the silver-based catalyst DEO to EGly, the presence forms of silver species influence their adsorption and activation behaviors on the feed gasses [19,22]. It further affects the activity of the catalyst. Nevertheless, due to the excessively high boiling point of DEO, the resulting DEO-TPD data suffer distortion. As a viable alternative, methyl acetate (MA) possesses a similar functional group and boasts a lower boiling point. In order to explore the correlation between the available forms of silver species and the intrinsic activities of the catalysts, MA-TPD is conducted on both the 10Ag/SiO2-HR and 10Ag/SiO2-WI catalysts. Fig. 5 a shows the TPD profiles of MA over 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst, with two distinct peaks observed at 100 °C and 300 °C, corresponding to the physisorption and chemisorption of MA, respectively. The chemisorption of the carbonyl groups in DEO, which is the rate-determining step of DEO hydrogenation, determines the conversion of the catalytic reaction [22]. By comparing the chemisorption peaks of both catalysts, it is evident that the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst exhibits a larger adsorption capacity and lower adsorption temperature. This enhanced adsorption capacity could be attributed to the presence of more silver sites, which is consistent with the smaller size of silver particles observed in the TEM. The disparity in desorption temperatures indicates differences in the dissociation and adsorption capacities of Ag0 and Ag+ for carbonyl groups. Additionally, UV–vis results demonstrat a high Ag+/(Ag0+Ag+) value on the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. Therefore, we could conclude that Ag+ possesses stronger carbonyl groups dissociation and adsorption capacity, which agrees with the previous study [19,22]. Ag+, as a Lewis acid, promotes the activation of oxygen atoms in the electron-rich carbonyl group through p-π conjugation [19,22,53]. DEO hydrogenation is a tandem reaction process, and EGly serves as an intermediate product. The strong adsorption of the carbonyl group may result in excessive hydrogenation, leading to the formation of ethylene glycol. This could explain the low selectivity observed for the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. 3.2.5 H2-TPD In the catalytic reaction of DEO to EGly, the degree of H2 adsorption and activation similarly determines the selectivity of EGly. For this reason, the development of silver-based catalysts has been pursued. Silver, due to its filled d-band, has a poor affinity for H2. This unique property gives it superior effect in the field of preliminary hydrogenation [11,26]. Fig. 5b shows the TPD profiles of H2 over 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. The presence of jittering curves indicates a low signal-to-noise ratio due to the poor hydrogen affinity. These jittery curves were fitted to reveal the actual desorption peaks. The bands observed at 50–100 °C and 300–550 °C correspond to the physisorption and chemisorption of H2, respectively. The broad adsorption band for hydrogen prevents the complete visualization of the peak. However, it is evident that the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst exhibits a greater adsorption capacity and lower desorption temperature. Similar to the inference of MA-TPD, we could conclude that Ag+ displays stronger dissociative adsorption of H2 compared to Ag0. This finding aligns with previous studies [54,55]. Ag+ has a stronger adsorption capacity for both carbonyls and hydrogen, which explains the low selectivity observed for the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. 3.3 Metal-support interactions Based on the discussion in the previous section, we have identified the different forms of silver species present on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. TEM and UV–vis DRS results suggest a potential connection between the electronic structure and geometry of these silver species and their interaction with the catalyst support. Therefore, this section focuses on MSIs to explore its influence on the catalyst structure. 3.3.1 Effect of metal particle sizes on MSIs Previous studies have found that, despite reducing the catalyst by harsh atmosphere, Ag+ remains present at the interface. This phenomenon could be attributed to the role of metal-support interactions [20,22,26]. It is evident that MSIs exert significant influence on the redox properties of these catalysts. Therefore, we conducted H2-TPR experiments to investigate the redox properties of the xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. Fig. 6 a illustrates the H2-TPR profiles of the xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts. The bands observed at 50–100 °C correspond to silver oxide, while the bands observed at 250–500 °C are attributed to Ag-O-Si species. The strength of the Ag-O-Si bond serves as an indicator to evaluate the strength of the MSIs. The greater the strength of the Ag-O-Si bond indicates the stronger the MSIs. For xAg/SiO2-HR catalysts with different loadings, the positions of the peaks corresponding to Ag-O-Si species are similar, indicating that the size of silver particles is not the primary factor influencing the MSIs in this system. 3.3.2 Effect of preparation method on MSIs Previous studies have demonstrated that the preparation method, particularly the addition of a reducing agent, is a crucial factor influencing the MSIs of catalysts [37–39]. Therefore, we employed H2-TPR to investigate the intensities of MSIs on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst, thereby exploring the effects of the preparation methods on the MSIs. In the above H2-TPR test, the peak of Ag2O showed incomplete. Additionally, low-temperature TPR could detect AgOx, which is highly susceptible to oxidation. Therefore, low-temperature H2-TPR starting at -30° was employed to detect different silver-oxygen components. Fig. 6b shows the profiles of H2-TPR on 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. The bands at 30–50 °C are attributed to AgOX, 50–110 °C to Ag2O, and 200–500 °C to Ag-O-Si bonds. It is obvious that the Ag-O-Si of 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst has a lower reduction temperature, which means that the catalysts prepared by the HR preparation method have weaker MSIs. It should be noted that the pre-reduction temperature was 300 °C. At this temperature, part of the Ag-O-Si in 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst has been reduced, while almost no Ag-O-Si in 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst has been reduced. This observation provides an explanation for the detection of Ag+ even after the reduction process. 3.3.3 Interfacial charge transfer Catalyst structures bridge MSIs and catalyst activities, especially the electronic structures of metal species at the interface. The occurrence of MSIs is usually accompanied by the rearrangement of electrons at the interface between the metal particles and the support. The redistribution of electrons is limited to a few atomic layers of the interface, which normally involves the change in the valence of metal atoms or support's metal ions nearby [31]. To accurately describe the electronic states at the surface and interface of the catalysts, we employed XPS to identify the surface silver valence states on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. Fig. 6c shows the Ag 3d XPS spectrum of the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst. Two prominent peaks are observed at 375 and 369 eV, corresponding to Ag0 3d3/2 and Ag0 3d5/2 signals, respectively. Distinguishing between Ag0 and Ag2O based solely on the Ag 3d signals is challenging due to their close proximity. Therefore, majority of scholars identify the pair via the peak shift and the alteration of the peak shape [22,26]. It could be clearly observed that the positions and shapes of these two peaks are slightly different. The peaks of 10Ag/SiO2-HR shifte toward higher binding energy, as well as the shapes of the peaks are more symmetrical. These results suggest a higher presence of Ag0 on the surface of the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst, which aligns with the UV–vis DRS results. Considering the charge correction might significantly affect the "0.2 eV offset", we adopt the Auger parameter to eliminate the bias. The Auger parameter not only avoids the bias caused by charge correction, but also improves the "resolution" of species in different chemical environments. Thus, it is commonly applied for the identification of chemical states of silver, copper, zinc and other species [56,57]. In this context, the Ag M4N45N45 signals (within the 354.2–358.2 eV range) in the Ag MNN spectrum serve as the standard of identifying the chemical state of silver. As shown in the Fig. 6d, the most significant signals of 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst and 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst are observed at 355.5 and 357.5 eV, corresponding to Ag2O and Ag0, respectively [26]. By combining the signal of Ag 3d in XPS (signal of the main peak) with the signal of Ag MNN in AES, the Auger parameters of the samples could be obtained by summing the binding energy and kinetic energy. Table 2 presents the Auger parameters of the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst as 724.5 and 726.2 eV, respectively. In the Auger parameter for silver, above 726 eV is considered as the presence of metal only, 724–726 eV as the presence of oxide, and below 724 eV as the presence of fluoride. These results indicate that the silver species on the surface of the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst predominantly exist in the form of Ag0, which corresponds to the findings from XPS and UV–vis DRS. This suggests that MSIs facilitate interfacial electron transfer from metal to support, leading to an increase in interfacial Ag+. 3.4 Structure-effect relationship Based on the discussions in the preceding sections, it has been established that there are distinct structural variances between the silver species on the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst and the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst, which consequently influence their interactions with the supports. Moreover, these structural distinctions have a profound impact on their adsorption behavior and subsequent activity. The following section aims to provide a summary of the aforementioned findings in order to elucidate the relationship between catalyst structure and activity. 3.4.1 Chemical valence of silver-Selectivity In silver-based catalytic oxalate hydrogenation systems, numerous studies have shown that the electron cloud density of silver plays a crucial role in determining the catalyst's ability to adsorb and activate the carbonyl group and H2 [19,22]. This conclusion is further supported by our present study. Silver with partial positive charge, as lewis acid, bonds more tightly to the carbonyl group and H2 through p-π conjugation. This enhanced binding promotes the adsorption and activation of the reactants. However, an over-activated carbonyl group and excessive adsorption of H2 will lead to a decrease in the selectivity of the target product, EGly. Similar observations have been reported in related studies [20]. Likewise, in copper-based catalysts, the increase in temperature and Cu+ ratio have been found to decrease the selectivity of the preliminary hydrogenation product [42–44]. Consistent with these findings, the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst, which contains a higher proportion of Ag0, exhibited higher selectivity across the entire temperature range compared to the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. In fact, for achieving maximum yield, there mighe be a trade-off between the adsorption activation of carbonyl and hydrogen, that is, there exists an optimal value of Ag+/(Ag++Ag0). However, this conjecture requires further verification in future studies. 3.4.2 Particle size and distribution-Conversion As the active center of oxalate hydrogenation, the size and distribution of silver nanoparticles, in addition to the valence state of the silver species, correlate with the activity as well. Due to the mutual limitation of electronic effects and geometric effects of Ag-based catalysts, both overly tiny silver particles and overly massive silver nanoparticles have poor activity. For reference, Dong et al. synthesized a series of Ag/AS catalysts with silver particle sizes ranging from 2.9 to 8.8 nm. They found that there is a trade-off between the number of active sites and the electronic structure, resulting in the highest apparent TOF reaction rate when the particle size was 5.3 nm [29]. Therefore, controlling the sizes of silver particles serve as an excellent strategy to improve silver utilization. Combining the BET, TEM, H2-TPD and DEO-TPD, it is obvious that the silver particles on 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst are more uniformly dispersed and smaller in size. This suitable silver particle size contributes to improved silver utilization. Consequently, for the equal silver loading, the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst offers a higher number of active sites, which explains its superior conversion performance. 4 Conclusions To summarize, we synthesized the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst using a novel H2O2 reduction method and compared it with the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst prepared via the excess impregnation-evaporating solvent method for the hydrogenation of DEO to EGly. The catalyst prepared by the H2O2 reduction method displays superior catalytic performance. At 260 °C and 1.5 MPa H2, the conversion of DEO reached 95.6%, and the selectivity of EGly reached 78.0%, representing a 37% improvement in yield compared to the 10Ag/SiO2-EE catalyst. Characterization of the geometric properties of silver particles revealed that silver particles on 10Ag/SiO2-HR are finer in size and uniformly dispersed, providing a higher number of active sites. This characteristic is responsible for its enhanced conversion performance. Furthermore, electronic property characterization of the silver species indicated the occurrence of MSIs between the silver and the support, resulting in a reduction of the electron cloud surrounding the silver. Weaker MSIs observed in the 10Ag/SiO2-HR catalyst allowed for a higher presence of Ag0, which contributes to its improved selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Ethyl glycolate (EGly) is a platform molecule in various fields, which has been widely applied for the production of various valuable chemicals. Despite being a traditional catalyst for the conversion of diethyl oxalate (DEO) to EGly, Ag/SiO2 catalyst exhibits insufficient activity. The present study introduces a novel preparation method that couples H2O2 reduction with deposition precipitation to augment the performance of the catalyst. Performance results show that Ag/SiO2 catalyst prepared by the new method attains a DEO conversion of 95.6% and an EGly selectivity of 78.0%, showing respective improvements of 10.0 and 15.2% over excess impregnation-evaporating solvent method. Characterization results show that the average silver particles size of Ag/SiO2 catalyst prepared by the new method is 6 nm, which is 1/2 of the excess impregnation-evaporation solvent method. Simultaneously, it contains a greater quantity of Ag0. The smaller and more uniform particles offer greater active site density, leading to enhanced DEO conversion. An increased presence of Ag0 diminishes DEO overactivation and inhibits the dissociative adsorption of H2. Moreover, the amplified quantity of Ag0 could be attributed to the reduced interfacial charge transport triggered by metal-support interactions (MSIs).
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed Ag/SiO2 catalyst with weak metal-support interaction for diethyl oxalate hydrogenation to ethyl glycolate
